Cutting Diet:

Maintenance:
Calories: TDEE

Adjust calories as needed based on your goals / results.

posts.com: Discuss everything dental related! Teeth, gums, ortho, you name it. Share your techniques or ongoing concerns regarding the one of the most temperamental parts of the human body.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Before bed, I take my things and go to the bathroom. I run hot water in the tap slightly. I fill up my mug with water. I then use the placker's picks to floss, and then I follow up with them using the GUM soft-picks. I rinse with water and spit it out. Then I use the tongue scraper and remove any bacterial film on my tongue, rinsing with water afterward. Then, I use my Oral-B rotating toothbrush and slowly pass over each tooth. This takes three passes, because of the three exposed sides of my teeth I cover. I then rinse again as I wash my toothbrush by buzzing it under the running water. After this, I fill some hydrogen peroxide into the mug, and mix it equally with water, then I swish it and gargle it vigorously. Every week or two I use toothpaste, but not every night.

I go to the dentist twice a year. As far as I'm aware I don't have any cavities, but I often have nightmares about losing teeth. I try not to eat too much acidic food, when I do I balance it out with something basic like the snake juice I fill up a water bottle with.

I realized everything that was holding me back was at its root my own self.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69927922
You're super shaky. Too much caffeine?
Form is fine but as the weight goes up you will wanna begin learning the lift in various stages rather than just kinda panicking and yeeting it up.
>Slightly wide conventional stance pick
>'Lap' the weight and bring your chest to the log
>Rotate arms so elbows are out
>Explode up while keeping log in contact with chest
>Roll/wedge arms up under the log, forearms vertical
>Hip/Leg drive by bending knees outward, not forward
>Explode up with drive + press

Notes:
>Keep elbows high when in front rack position or the log will roll down your body and you lose a good position
>It's tempting to keep arms in neutral grip for the roll but this can tear biceps fast af and is weaker overall
>Core braced the whole damn time and when you're in the front rack position CLENCH YOUR GLUTES to keep rigidly upright
>Knees outward on the drive because going forward will risk balance and doesn't transfer as well, also might make torso lean forward and lose the log

Good luck anon. I'm not perfect at em but I dabbled with em at a gym in OKC that had a Rogue log for a couple weeks and hit 235.

If I had more frequent/full-time access to the log I'd do:

>Full range comp style reps
>Log deadlifts with heavier weight than comp
>Incline Bench or Standing OHP with the log out of rack
>Log Cleans

All in an effort to build up the main comp movement. This might be a dumb take but, I'm sure the 2 strongman guys here will have input.

So, the grip of your hand is of course neutral but you can adjust your arm position relative to the floor/the log to adjust how you get it up. Youtube is your best friend here, Brian Alsruhe has a video guide or two.
Best text I can offer is to imagine you lay flat on a bench and do close grip reps with the log, but instead of coming down so your forearm stays vertical you come down by just drifting your elbows out. Now apply the way it'd look at the bottom of that CG press, to the way you hold it out of your lap from the bottom.

If you're starting out, I'd personally just take things simple & not worry too much about all the "serious" stuff. Just either get some weights for the start of a home gym or get a gym membership and start working out. After you spend a month or two like that maybe you can start looking into stuff like programs, diets, caloric intake, pre workouts, protein shakes etc. etc.
Just start & see where it takes you and try not to quit, the more you try to do the more likely you'll be to quit.

As a skeleton, I put on 20kg of weight from working out when I couldn't put on fat so while you do need a caloric surplus I don't think you need to bulk before you make muscle & you definitely don't need to cut before you start building muscle

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69929958
"definition" is just low bodyfat. Given your stated goal, you should just put the fork down and lose weight, that's it. But realistically, you probably just don't know what you actually need to look the way you want.
Starting Strength is exactly what it says in the name, it starts you off on getting strength. It's a beginner program that will let you get your noob gains quickly. There are others like it. You do it until you stall out (provided you actually ate enough etc) and then do something else depending on your goals - aesthetics, olympic lifts, powerlifting, whatever. It also greatly benefits from smart isolation exercises for muscles that don't get hit much by the main compound lifts.
I think you should just follow a beginner strength program and just do a full bulk/cut cycle once. By the time you're done you will probably have a better understanding of what you want and you will have significantly improved your physique.

>>69930243
Yep, they are periods of time to reach a goal. On your question on what you do between google the phrase "maintenance calories". When you bulk remember to up your intensity in the gym - the whole point of bulking is that you have more fuel to go harder. IF you're on a cut an losing bodyweight rather than fat percentage you likely need to up your training intensity (i.e. how much effort you're expending, not necessarily more sessions or longer sessions), and not prioritising protein.

>>69929958
Starting strength is fine. PPL is also fine. Either is better than no program at all - don't get analysis paralsis by forever comparing programs and never actually sticking to one. Pick one, do it for 3 months. If at the end of the 3 months you don't like it, then change. Don't program hop after a few weeks.

>>69930005
You'll get more effective gains by upping intensity on your training days and actually having proper rest days with some low intensity cardio. Training every day is a classic 'high floor, low ceiling' situation in terms of potential progress. Also, get non-lifting hobbies and schedule all your socialising on rest days to make them fly by.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69938389
If you do one set of one exercise and then do a different exercise the next set and so on, that's called super setting. Most of the time, if someone has 3 sets of curls in their workout, they'll do one set of curls, rest, do another set of curls, and so on.
You can choose to do either way, but most people don't superset their entire workout for the day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sunday edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For driven ducks who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69938925
None, as in don't eat. It's the quickest way to lose weight/fat and once you get the hang of it you don't even feel hungry after a while, you will feel more tired as usual though. If fasting isn't really your thing then I recommend going on a high-protein diet while still being in a caloric deficit. Foods like tuna, chicken, whey protein, eggs. Get around 0.8 grams of protein per pound of bodyweight. Not saying to cut off veggies and shit but focus more on getting your protein. Honestly whatever you eat really doesn't matter as long as you expend more calories than you consume, it's just that protein and meat in general are very satiating and it helps retain your muscles.

checked
part of it is learning how to modify recipes to fit your tastes, calorie count, and macros. ie, use chicken breast instead of thigh, use less rice, use a pump oil in a nonstick pan instead of and ounce of butter, etc.
that said, budgetbytes.com really helped me when i was young and starting to learn how to cook on my own without my parents. no bullshit stories about how her dad spent a summer in italy, just info on the recipe. THEN she posts photos for every step in the process. super helpful when you're a novice. her focus is on cutting cost, but i still find her content enjoyable.
also, emilybites.com has been useful. lightened-up comfort food, i think is her tagline. she used weight watchers to categorize stuff, and i very often use twice to three times the amount of meat that she calls for and play with serving sizes, but everything that i've had has been pretty solid.
on youtube, ethan cheblowski (i think i got that right) has had some excellent videos lately on meal prep and cooking in ways that won't bore you. i don't fully agree with his video on "braise this meat on sunday and then eat it in different ways the rest of the week", necessarily, but still good stuff. if you're new to cooking, skip his deep dives, but those are still interesting. also he has older videos where he makes a "normal" recipe and a lower calorie version. recommend. he used to be fat and isn't anymore, so i guess he knows the struggle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69940702

You don't need a huge surplus to put on lean mass. If I remember correctly at best you can add like 0.5-1.0 lb of lean mass a week. So a few hundred calories surplus is probably enough. And with noob gains you need even less of a surplus.

Try eating at maintenance for a month or so and see what happens. Keep track of weight and other measurements (waist, chest, etc) and see how it changes.

If you are managing it well, then bump up to eating at a small surplus, like a couple hundred calories. And see what happens with that.

And if you start adding more fat than you want, well then you know what to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69940755

Get a scale with biometric impedance to measure body fat. Most of them that have it will also measure lean mass, bone and water weight as well.

Then also do the tape method (also known as circumference method) to measure body fat. Or get fat calipers and learn how to use those.

None of them are all that accurate, they have a margin of error of a couple percentage points probably.

But if you do two or three methods, and they all match up pretty closely, or move in the same direction, then you can be pretty certain of what is going on with your body as far as body fat goes.

And your ideal goal would be for it to not move at all or go down slightly as you gain lean mass. In reality you'll probably put on a bit of fat, especially if you do eat at a surplus, but it will be up to you to determine what you are ok with adding before you want to cut again.

The important thing is you know how to lose fat when you want to now. So you can experiment and try things and figure out what works for you. And if something isn't working you can tweak it and fix it.

posts.com:
>>69941374
For exercises that have a high chance of you getting stuck under a load such as squats and bench presses, ALWAYS perform them inside a power cage or with a rack that has safety pins set at the right height (for example, setting the safety pins few inches below the lowest the bar can get during squats so when you get stuck you can just tip forward and the bar will land on the pins)
Practice correct form with light weights and only increase the weight if you got the form right.
And don't forget to warm up

posts.com:
/FAST/ #28 Anti-Flab Commando Ed
WAGMI bros

FAQ:
> What do I need to start?
- To keep your hands and food away from your piehole
>Beginner's routine?
Start skipping either breakfast or dinner, track your weight daily with a set weigh-in time. If the progress slows, go from 16:8 to something like 20:4 (four hours to eat) or One Meal A Day (OMAD). GET ELECTROLYTES

>I'm a hamplanet that's new to fasting, can I just jump into 3day+ extended fasting?
-Only if you want to burn muscle mass and lean tissue because you aren't fat-adapted retard
>How can I get fat-adapted?
-Do 16:8 or more daily fasting for about 2 months or do keto for a similar length of time if you don't want to feel you're starving or start losing muscle mass

> I want to do a longer fast, what do I need?
- Snake juice and peace
> What is snake juice?
- 1.5 tbsp salt, 1 tsp potassium chloride (nu-salt, no-salt), magnesium citrate/chloride (optional, check for epsom salts) to 2 liters of water
> I feel hungry!
- You shouldn't feel hungry after the first day, if you do and are new, try switching to keto macros and restarting the fast later

>Recommended macros?
- 70% fat, 25% protein, 5% carbs. Keep carbs below 50g total.
- P:E diet - 50% or more protein, <40% fat <10% carbs

>I'm sub 20bf, want to get lean, but don't want to lose muscle
- OMADEOD
>I'm sub 12% and not sleeping well
eat a tiny protein meal 3 hours before bed on your "full" day of the 48
>I'm gaining weight on OMAD
-You're FUCKING UP, weigh your meal components and record in cronometer (free). Add light cardio or standing or switch to OMEOD so you can continue to eat like fat pig.

>LIFE Fasting Circle Group (group fasting tracker for iOS & Android)
https://lifefastingtracker.app.link/Kf9tSyuowmb
Or Search "/fast/"

Post 'em

>CW (current weight)
>SW (starting weight)
>height
>fasting schedule

There is no such thing as a repetitive question

from everything I read, lifting and fasting just don't go together.
you can't get any protein, so you could get very little gains or even none at all. and also, there's basically a "switch" in your body that turns it from muscle building mode to muscle breakdown mode. this "switch" is controlled by insulin, so basically when you fast you will always be in a muscle breakdown mode.

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 miles/10km, start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for suggested plans)

>Couch to 5k Guide
https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/exercise/running-and-aerobic-exercises/get-running-with-couch-to-5k/
>Sprinters Guides

>I want to run a fast 5k, 10k, half-marathon, or marathon
https://www.runningfastr.com/ (with goal times)
https://www.halhigdon.com/ (more planning necessary but more thorough workouts/explanations)
>Stretching guide
https://www.runnersworld.com/uk/training/beginners/a32172701/how-to-stretch-post-run/

People are scared of change or to admit it, since they're used to the mainstream acceptable or are just bound by sunk cost.

>>69923932
The cheapest leg press I'd even is the titan vertical leg press for $500. a cheap squat rack is $200-300, and a decent barbell is about $200. Obviously either way you're going to need to buy plates. If you spring for quality, a good linear leg press like the one in your pic is easily 2k-6k, while getting a top of the line squat rack and barbell is going to be at the most, 2k-3.
With a leg press you can do: leg press, single leg press, and calf press. With a barbell and squat rack you can do squats, deadlifts, calf raises, OHP, pull ups...
Not to mention squat racks have a crazy amount of attachments. If you add a pulley attachment, you have access to probably 80-90% of traditional weighted exercises.
Advising anyone to buy a leg press before a squat rack is ridiculous.

M/W/F; A/B/A, B/A/B, repeat.

A1: pullups, band assisted 3 - 4 x 6 - 12 reps, OR negatives. Gradually accumulate negatives per workout, then per week until you can do pullups.
A2: dumbbell OHP 3 - 4 x 6 - 12.
A3: Goblet squat 3 -4 x 6 - 12.
A4: curls, 3 sets 8 - 12 reps.
A5: tricep extensions, 3 sets 8 - 12 reps.

B1: dumbbell rows, same sets and reps.
B2: dumbbell bench, " "
B3: dumbbell RDL, " "
B4: curls, tricep ext, lateral raises super set; 3 sets per exercise, 8 - 12 reps.

posts.com:
>>69934716
>what's your opinion on not getting rack+barbell and just use clubs and kbs exclusively for a homegym
you won't get super huge or move massive weight like you could with a barbell, but you'd be getting conditioning and endurance as a tradeoff to that. I got my start with traditional barbell work but switched to KBs and clubs later on.
barbells are superior for lower body time under tension work, kettlebells are better for overhead pressing if you have even a hint of an impingement or bone spur in your acromion. It's safer to do high rep power work with Kettlebells.
>If you do go the kb/club home gym route
I like Mark Wildman and Joe Daniels as resources for clubs and kbs because they are no nonsense and acknowledge that they are one tool among many with inherent pros and cons. a lot of ballistic fitness folks are insufferable about PRIMAL FUNCTIONAL CAVEMAN FUNCTIONAL MOVEMENT SUPREMACY cope. so be warned about that stuff.
I also recommend getting a strongman sandbag, Iron mind loads to 300lb and rogue I think to 400. Sand or gravel is cheap or free. Use that for things like lap and load, bear hug carries and zercher squats. These are going to fill the void you can't easily get from kettlebells and takes less space than a rack and barbell, but the tradeoff is it takes a while to load them. I recommend many small liners filled with sand. 300 may not seem like a lot but a beltless sandbag zercher is much harder than a corresponding barbell back squat.
hope this helps and good luck

circuit: do curls, tricep ext, and lat raise back-to-back with no rest. rest 2 - 3 min, then repeat for a total of 3 times.

double progression example: pick a weight you can do 3 sets of 6 reps with. as you get stronger, add reps to the sets until you hit 3 x 12. then increase the weight and start at 3 x 6 again. repeat the process.

posts.com:
>>69930467
6-12 months depending on what you’re working with (body size). You need to be methodical about the process. Most people are not methodical; it shows.

You do not get a 315 BP by only doing the lift once a week or every 2 weeks. You don’t get it fucking around with chest exercises that are not bench press. You don’t get it by constantly repping the same (low) weight every week. If you keep doing 225 for reps every time you bench, you are not going to magically bench 315 one day. Your body is used to what it’s used to. You need to keep adding weight or reps as often as possible barring injury, illness, or time spent away from where you train. If you’re smaller (say under 200lbs), accept that this process is going to take longer than if you were bigger.

Do the exercise every 4-6 days. Get really comfortable with doing bench press. A lot of being good at bench press is having good technique. Learn to use your legs to drive if you’re in an emergency and need to get the weight up. Use wrist wraps if you need to on higher weight. Don’t ego lift, that’s how you fuck your shoulders up. Do your working sets at 2-4 reps so you’re less likely to injure yourself and so you can exhibit good control of the bar. If your back comes off, work at a lower weight. Take lots of time between sets if you need to. Do a long warm ups. Wear a sweater to keep your shoulders and chest warm.

Eat egg whites like it’s your job. Do accessory exercises like weighted pull ups and overhead press. Do other triceps exercises. Being good at bench press means having strong muscles aside from your chest to help stabilize the bar.

Are lots of people being this conscientious when it comes to training for bench press? No, they’re not. That’s why they can’t bench 315. If I told you that if you couldn’t bench 315 by one year from today that you would die, would you be able to figure out how to do it? Yeah, you probably would.

>Everything I desire is not even in front of me to work on at this moment in my life

I eat 5 eggs per day and it's the best tasting and satisfying meal I eat all day. I've literally not had better eggs from any of the cafes i've been to that serve scrambled eggs on toast etc.

All you need are:

eggs
olive oil
salt
pepper
cheddar cheese

I literally just eyeball it using the gordan ramsay egg cooking method

1.Put pan on high heat with tablespoon of olive oil
2. as pan is heating, pull out eggs and start cracking them into a bowl
3. get a tble spoon of grass fed butter (NO CANOLA OIL OR OTHER SHIT IN THE BUTTER) and add to egg bowl. DO NOT MIX THE EGGS.
4. take the pan off the heat (keep fire lit), and pour eggs into the pan
5. very quickly pop all the yolks and start mixing with spatula as they will cook fast.
6. once cooking really slows down, add back to the heat (go on and off to prevent over cooking)
7. Just before the eggs approach the perfect moistness/fluffiness, take it off the heat completely and add your cheese in and mix to let the cheese melt.

Salt and pepper to taste and done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
avoid PUFA
eat collagen
eat saturated fat
Those are probably the most important dietary things.

The structural components of your body are formed from Fat and Protein.
PUFAs are inflammatory unstable fats, and so avoiding them limits this cause of aging.
Sulphur amino acids (methionine, cysteine) are inflammatory and unstable, and accumulate with age. Consuming collagen (which is abundant in glycine) helps the liver to excrete excess methionine, and so reduces chronic inflammation. Another strategy is eating some canned beans a few times a week, as legumes are deficient in cysteine. Methionine reduction is one of the biggest strategies for anti-aging. However going full methionine restriction will age you like a vegan, so it's more about balance. Neither too much nor too little is best.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69941435
>https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34668663/


>You already burn 0 muscle in the first 10 days of a fast.
See pic of the study you cite. It clearly shows that muscle is lost and "0" muscle lost is false. If it were true then pro bodybuilders would use this method to get ripped.
>Your growth hormone is cranked through the fucking roof while fasting.
Your body becomes growth hormone resistant during a fast.
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11861499/
Growth hormone is a stress hormone designed to increase the bodies use of fat during stress such as fasting and heavy exercise.
>This helps to preserve muscle.
There is no evidence that growth hormone builds or maintains muscle in healthy adults.
https://bjsm.bmj.com/content/bjsports/37/2/100.full.pdf
>You can even build muscle
You need a positive nitrogen balance to build muscle, muscle is lost during a fast due to the negative nitrogen balance. That's why the body needs xx grams of protein per day to maintain muscle.
>Just make sure to stop within 6-10 days though, before your organs are tapped out and you need to start eating muscle instead
The loss of muscle during fasting is highest at the beginning when the body is transitioning to ketones and slows down the longer you fast.

>>69931947

That’s not how it works. People’s endurance improves in thin air (like at altitude) because less oxygen causes them to develop a high red blood cell count, which improves oxygen delivery. But working out in thin air conditions actually makes your workout less effective because you’re training your heart itself (which is a muscle) and you’re not able to push it as hard because you’re limited by the low oxygen delivery. The top endurance training programs in the world generally live high up at altitude and will drive down to lower altitudes to work out (the exact opposite of living in normal air then oxygen restricting yourself to work out). Your VO2max likely improved because you were focusing on it and training it consistently, in spite of the mask not because of it.

>>69938194
It's an observational study so provides no conclusion as to whether it is causative or not. Basically studies like this can only provide a correlation, and we have no idea if napping causes poor health, or vice versa, or some third confounding variable related to both causes both behaviours (ie, genetics).

The study can only highlight the need for a further study where causation can actually be implied: a randomly sampled trial with a control group

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69937366
Do everything on this list with slow eccentrics and pauses for even more torture
>legs
1.5 rep (down, halfway up, down, all the way up) ATG high-bar close-stance squats, high reps
Deficit RDLs (optionally wide grip as well), again high reps
High-bar 45 degree back extensions, again high reps
3 count pause bulgarian split squats, these are the most painful shit ever
Absurdly big ROM on all of these (besides BSS), huge time under tension, and you'll get insane DOMS from both of those. But you'll also get bulletproof knees and super flexible hamstrings, which is great obviously
>upper body compounds
Horizontal pressing isn't particularly difficult desu, can't think of anything that'd be really hard. Maybe weighted dips/weighted ring dips in the 15-20 rep range
Deficit strict barbell rows, 15 reps minimum.
Strict OHP, 15 reps minimum. Slow eccentric is especially effective here
Vertical pulls aren't particularly hard either, maybe do weighted chinups in the 15-20 rep range. Or maybe try doing super wide grip pullups, then do a mechanical dropset into chinups once you hit failure since chinups are much easier than super wide grip pullups
>isolation
Sissy squats are fucking torturous, do these for 15+ reps. Add weight if you can. Be careful, progress slowly so your knees don't explode
Calf raises to eccentric failure are also very painful, maybe try those too (need to do them single leg tho)
High-rep nordic curls are also very painful, give these a go (band assisted if you can't do full reps yet)
Weighted situps (hold the weight behind your head, it's much harder), do an absurd amount of myo-reps once you hit failure. Very painful stuff
>mental exercises
Dual-n back training, once you get better move up to triple-n back or even quad-n back. Very mentally straining, I recommend it. Meditate as well.

Might drop some more stuff if this thread is still up tomorrow

>>69937366
The exercises I’ve found satisfy this most for me are the ones that can get incredibly excruciating but don’t overtax the entire body/energy systems. Because you can really keep pushing with the limiting factor truly being pain tolerance and muscle failure. For pure pain for me, it’s
>Calves
Seated calf raises, 5 second eccentric, 5 second pause, slow concentric, pause.
>Forearms
Superset a bunch of wrist curls and extensions in particular, some behind the back curls, some abductions. The pump from doing intense low-rest forearm work is really something else.

For overall pain including energy systems, I’d say burpees with needing to push harder on every jump and there’s no “settling into it”. Or very slow eccentric zercher squats.

Anterior pelvic tilt is usually the biggest and most difficult issue to address. Shoulders were actually pretty easy to fix for me with face pulls y raises and band pull aparts also keeping my shoulders back on all pressing exercises. Neck a little tougher but fixed it doing neck curls on a bench with a dumbell on a towel on my forehead. Also did rear neck curls, side neck curls, and twists. Counterintuitively you want to strengthen the muscles on the front of your neck the most to pull your head/chin down instead of having it jut forward

posts.com: How do I go about balancing strength training with cardio for boxing? Before getting into the sport, I worked off the Texas Method for a bit. Now I'm trying to supplement cardio (sprints + 5k runs) into the work I already do for boxing, and I have no idea how to even fit strength training into it. Pls help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69939456
Strength training almost doesn't matter at all for boxing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69939456
Focus the most on the deadlift, OHP, pullups, and bench press about twice per week. Focus more on explosiveness and speed than brute strength. Also add arm work, shrugs, and things like wood choppers and other rotational exercises to your sessions. Otherwise you want to be doing lots of calisthenics basically every day. Your biggest concerns are your speed, muscular endurance, and especially your cardio. The bigger you can make your gastank while building your speed and muscular endurance the better
t. former heavyweight boxer

Pull
> Pull-ups
> Diddlies
> Row exercise, prefer cables to spare lowerback
> Facepulls
> Hammer curls
> Bicep curl
> (SHRUGS)

Push
> Bench
> Incline Bench
> (I'd add cable flies cause i want bigger tits)
> OHP (can do OHP first every other workout instead of bench)
> Any lateral raise
> Skullcrushers or overhead triceps exercise
> Tricep extensions pushdowns thing
> (SHRUGS)

Legs
> Main squat compound exercise
> RDLs or any diddly accessory, posterior chain
> Bulgarian split squats
> Calf raise of your choice I do seated atm
> Hyperextentions for gloots
> Leg raises
> Cable crunches

These movements should cover most of the muscles. Just pick whatever exercise variation you enjoy, dumbell benching or cable/dumbell rowing up to you. Pull/Push/Legs/x REPAT is imo the superior scheduling to rest lower back between diddlies and squat but take a rest day whenever you need it. Throw in shrugs if you want bigger traps wherever you feel like.

>Advice for new runners
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 miles/10km, start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training plan for that goal (see below for suggested plans)

>Couch to 5k Guide
https://www.nhs.uk/live-well/exercise/running-and-aerobic-exercises/get-running-with-couch-to-5k/
>Sprinters Guides
https://trackstarusa.com/

https://www.runningfastr.com/ (with goal times)
https://www.halhigdon.com/ (more planning necessary but more thorough workouts/explanations)

https://www.runnersworld.com/uk/training/beginners/a32172701/how-to-stretch-post-run/

posts.com:
How important is cardio during a lean/clean bulk?

To put this into perspective I have been on a -500 caloric deficit diet for 8 months. I've lost 65lbs and am now lean however I lack muscle definition, badly. My ENTIRE 8 month process followed a cycle like this:
monday: lifting set A
tuesday: cardio (swimming)
wed: lifting set B
thurs: cardio (jogging)
fri: lifting set A
sat: cardio (swimming)
(repeats)

The lifts focused on compound lifts, some ab exercises, etc.
However all this did was preserve SOME muscle mass as I was still dropping weight like crazy. Now I am switching to a +200 surplus going from my -500 deficit with the goal of gaining muscle while minimizing fat gains. I will not do a dirty bulk.

However what do I do about cardio now? is it still as important as it always has been? should I still follow the same routine I always have? what role does cardio play for muscle gain process

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69940489
Generally you will look better if you cut via exercise and not via diet, but if you are short on time or you're overtraining, it doesn't hurt to reduce your cardio.

Anorexia is more immediately dangerous than obesity, putting on or dropping 5% of your body weight is nothing if you’re 150lbs but if you’re 80lbs then losing that 5% could be lethal. Meanwhile, obeastoids can reach 600lbs or more and still be alive, though it obviously won’t be for much longer. This coupled with the body image self esteem push back in the 00s in response to 90s’ glorification of near-anorexic women’s’ bodies made anything to do with anorexia a very sensitive issue. However, the fat acceptance movement catching on more and more around the same time provided the perfect opportunity for deluded lards and other "special interest groups" (the fast food and medical industries) to push for fat acceptance. If thin bad, then fat good??? Utterly ridiculous line of thinking but that kind of reactionary shit is very appealing to people who feel marginalised, be it genuine or not, so we now have a society where morbid obesity is accepted and praised while anorexia is demonised. Both are terrible and will kill you, one just kills quicker than the other while the other is easy to make money off, so corporations, grifters, and genuine retards all did what they do best and here we are. Everything was just timed very conveniently, it probably wouldn’t have caught on even just a decade earlier.

Some basics about for you algorithms and other "you might be interested in..." type deals
They show you what you spend the most time on, and also stuff that results in different behavior other than scroll, scroll, scroll. Did you want mostly video games but keep on getting popping pimples? it's because you pause and watch for a bit whenever they pop up. Political shit? because you open up the comments and check whatever stupid shit they're saying. You'll get a mix of general pop humor and trending stuff, like celebs or that one joke video you've seen 5 times before. This bitch keeps on seeing thin transformation vids because she interacts with them, which the algorithm recognizes as interest. If she had true confidence and just kept scrolling past, she wouldn't keep seeing them
tl;dr she sees those vids, because negative interest is still interest

Real honest to goodness overtraining takes longer than one to two weeks, recovery time is measured in months.
So many of the bodies systems get crushed, the immune system, hormonal system, energy system, central nervous system.
Just think how long it take some people to recover from something like covid, or recover their test levels after roiding, it can take months for the body to get back to normal equilibrium when it's systems are crushed down by the constant battering and stress on the body from overworking it non stop without adequate rest and nutrition.
There has been lots of scientific investigation into the overtraining syndrome over the past century.

>>69939874
Not him but ring dips are better for your shoulders (and clavicles/sternum) because they can move to accomodate for your build, while you're locked in when doing parallel bar dips which can irritate your shoulder/clavicles/sternum. Also they're better for strengthening your rotator cuff than parallel bar dips (though I think direct work is still better) so that helps for protecting your shoulders on other motions. Ring dips are much harder than normal dips, the main thing is that you need to spend a good amount of time on the rings so you can gain the strength to actively stabilize them well. 3-4 sets of ring pushups, ring dips, or ring support position 2 times per week would probably be good

Go for the 1k deficit option anon. Read this next part twice so it sinks in: This 500 cal deficit thing is something we've taken from bodybuilders preparing for bodybuilding competitions. When you're cutting from 10 to 5% bodyfat, a 500 calorie deficit is more appropriate to avoid muscle loss, general fatigue, poor gym performance & extreme cravings. Problem is, this doesn't apply to regular lifters who are well above 12% bodyfat who want to lose some weight. You've got energy on your body in the form of fat. Eat protein, be hydrated, have a little bit of carbs via potatoes, greens, beans, oats, & don't worry about losing muscle at this stage.

>>69940544
>hip flexors
L-sit progression
Hanging leg raises (toes to bar ideally)
Seated leg lifts
Figure out a way to attach a db to your foot to do standing hip flexions (ideal exercise IMO, since you can easily overload without any problems). I think some people do something similar with cables as well
Ideally you want both bent leg and straight leg hip flexion movements, as straight leg movements will bias the rectus femoris more while bent leg will bias the other hip flexors more.
>abductors
I personally get my abductor work from single leg work since overdeveloped abductors can cause inverted triangle ass which looks like shit. But if they're underdeveloped by all means use the abductor machine
>adductors
Adductor machine
Weighted tailor's pose (performed dynamically instead of as a stretch, also elevate your hips and feet for more ROM when you can)
Copenhagen planks (can be performed statically or dynamically, can add weight as well)
>piriformis
Pigeon pose good mornings off of an incline bench (so that your piriformis is under load), add weight when you can and reduce the incline as you get more flexible

posts.com: Even though a lot of technologies and arrangements that're familiar to us like cars and drive thrus existed, things were less mechanized in general, like if you wanted to set the lockers on your truck you had to get out and manually do each one, now anything like that on your vehicle probably isn't even a physical button at this point. Cars needed constant servicing, like every time you drove shit had to be adjusted and maintained, you'd either do it or have to go to a service station, and it involved cranking stuff and bending down or reaching under parts of the vehicle. Power tools existed but were like 3 times as heavy as what we have today and even more times expensive, so maybe certain task on a site where it conferred the most advantage you'd be using a skilsaw or one of those giant two handed drills they had but most of the day you were using hand saws and swinging a hammer. Powered lawnmowers weren't common, let alone ride on ones, they used the ones that have blades in a drum you push manually you might have seen. People look at how more people are office workers relative to working in a factory or something and point to that but it's not even that simple, the physical demands even on a guy who worked behind a desk were different back then, and were very intense for someone who didn't

After growing up in the great depression with not enough to eat, they spent years under wartime rations while they beat the shit out of japs and krauts. So before 1945 there's not even an opportunity to get fat really.

Not really though. Your sodas are 6 oz each, and usually split with someone else. People drink soft drinks like they're hard liquor- just a couple ounces every now and again. Relatively rare in the 1950s, consumed as a special treat and definitely not 24/7, with relatively modest portion sizes.
